dataList.content: During the final stretch of each chapter, you’ll be exploring a <Dungeon>, a branch facility of the former L Corp.
Designate the Identities who will enter the Dungeon with you. You can’t adjust your team once inside, so choose wisely.
When you’re fully prepared, press the [Enter] button.

Your goal is to reach the last section of the bottom floor and retrieve the Golden Bough.
The Dungeon consists of multiple floors, each rife with events and encounters.
Clear the sector at the end of the floor to proceed to the next.

Each sector is connected to one or more paths.
You can travel to adjacent sectors by selecting them.
It’s possible to retrace your steps, so feel free to explore where you want first.

Sinners don’t heal after battle while in Dungeons.
Sinners with 0 HP are unable to participate, so keep track of their status.
Reaching a checkpoint will allow you to fully restore your Sinners.
After losing a battle, you can reattempt it from the start with whatever living Sinners remain on your full team.

You can find checkpoints as you explore the Dungeon.
Your Sinners will fully heal their HP and reset their SP upon reaching one.
When all of your Sinners die, you’ll be brought back to your last checkpoint.
Do note that progress made beyond said checkpoint will be reset as well.

Abnormalities consist of at least one body part.
Each part has its own slots, as well as individual skills.

Each Abnormality part has slots with the skills it intends to use.
The parts also have Speed values that determine their order of action.
If you target a skill slot with a Sinner whose Speed is higher, they can redirect that attack and Clash with it.

When the HP of a body part is reduced to 0, it is <Broken>.
A broken part becomes vulnerable to all physical attack types.
Some parts may lose certain skills or passives after breaking.
Do note that some Abnormalities have regenerative parts, as well as that breaking certain ones may instead enrage an Abnormality.

The Abnormality Encyclopedia records information on Abnormalities and their parts.
By nature, the Encyclopedia starts out incomplete.
The more you fight an Abnormality, the more its entry will be penned in the Encyclopedia.
After enough encounters, the Observation Level for the Abnormality will go up.
Higher Observation Levels increase the damage you deal against an Abnormality.

Checks presented by Abnormalities have a required Sin Affinity and a threshold to pass.
Choose a Sinner with the right affinity for a higher likelihood of success.
The Abnormality will react differently depending on your choice and its results.
Passing the check usually gives you benefits, and failing it burdens you with disadvantages.

You can find checkpoints as you explore the Dungeon.
Your Sinners will fully heal their HP and reset their SP upon reaching one.
When all of your Sinners die, you’ll be brought back to your last checkpoint.
Do note that progress made beyond said checkpoint will be reset as well.

For the combat phase to begin, every Sinner must be given an order.
In regular battles, you select skills by chaining them across the Dashboard, from the left gear to the right one.

Each skill consists of at least 1 Coin, which represents the number of attacks it can perform.
The Coin is tossed when the attack is initiated, and its outcome may boost or reduce the Power of the skill.
This modifier carries over to the next Coin if there is one.
The two types of Coins are plus (+) and minus (-).

On the Dashboard, a new column is added for one random Sinner each turn, up to a total of 12.
Sinners that have gained one will not receive another until all of their allies gain one of their own.
Once every Sinner has an additional column, they are all once again eligible.
Enemies also gain additional slots as the battle goes on.
Passive abilities activate when skills of certain Affinities are chained.

Select a Sinner’s skill, then drag it to one of the Abnormality’s slots to designate the target.
Note that each skill slot represents a different body part.
